unit_learning_outcomes.description: Have knowledge of the principles and concepts of a basic theory of partial differential equations.
Demonstrate efficient use of Fourier analysis techniques in the theory of partial differential equations.
Use the ideas and techniques of the theory of partial differential equations to model a broad range of phenomena in science and engineering (in particular using the heat and wave equations).
Construct logical, clearly presented and justified mathematical arguments incorporating deductive reasoning especially in the context of the theory of partial differential equations.
Understand the breadth of the theory of partial differential equations and its role in other fields.
Further studies in the areas of partial differential equations and advanced analysis.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Class preparation time includes revising new content as soon as possible after lectures in order to identify, and fix, any issues before the next lecture.

enrolment_rules.description: MATH3901 or MATH3902 or MATH3905 or MATH3909 or MATH331 or MATH332 or MATH335 or MATH339
(MATH2010 or MATH235) and (MATH2020 or MATH2110 or MATH232 or MATH236)

assessments.description: Assignment based on material from lectures in previous weeks.
In class test based on material from lectures in previous weeks.
Assignment based on material from lectures in previous weeks.
Test based on material from lectures in previous weeks. Students will submit scanned solutions on iLearn. They will be given a certain window during which they must submit the test.
This will be held during the final exam period. It will test the ability of students to synthesise the concepts taught in the course in order to analyse and solve partial differential equations.

Session 2, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 2, Special circumstances
data.description: Partial differential equations form one of the most fundamental links between pure and applied mathematics. Many problems that arise naturally from physics and other sciences can be described by partial differential equations. Their study gives rise to the development of many mathematical techniques, and their solutions enrich both mathematics and their areas of origin. This unit explores how partial differential equations arise as models of real physical phenomena, and develops various techniques for solving them and characterising their solutions. Special attention is paid to three partial differential equations that have been central in the development of mathematics and the sciences - Laplace's equation, the wave equation and the diffusion equation. This unit also introduces the idea of implementing computational methods for solving partial differential equations on mathematical software using ideas from numerical analysis.
data.title: Partial Differential Equations
